document.title: Class View and Object Browser Features

paragraph.paragraph: Feature nodes are visible from expanding a classes.xmlClass Node or expanding one of the subnodes under an expanded feature node. There are many different types of url*feature in Eiffel; for a full glossary of the features and their associated icon representation in the index.xmlClass View and ../object_browser/index.xmlObject Browser please refer to the eiffel_icons.xmlClass View and Object Browser Icons documentation.
If you do not already know what a url*feature is in Eiffel, please refer to the url*Eiffel for .NET Language documentation.
Expanding a feature node displays statuary information on the feature and its use within the project. The display items are listed below:

Ancestor version ../images/feature/hier_feature_ancestors.ico
A flattened list of all redefined versions of the expanded feature.

Decendent version ../images/feature/hier_feature_descendents.ico
A flattened list of all decended versions of the expanded feature.

Callers ../images/feature/hier_feature_callers.ico
A flattened list of all features that in turn call the expanded feature.

Implementers ../images/feature/hier_feature_implementers.ico
When expanded, a flattened list of all homogeneous features will be displayed.

If you need to direct the ../../eiffel_editor/index.xmlEiffel Editor to any feature found in the index.xmlClass View, a double-left mouse click on a corresponding feature node will open the url*Eiffel class in the editor and move the feature into view.
Note: The index.xmlClass View will show .NET types when using the facilities to browse classes.xmlclass and feature url*ancestors, url*decendents, etc. Attempts to locate the related source will instead open the ../object_browser/index.xmlObject Browser and locate the appropriate node given the assembly, type and feature.

When using the ../object_browser/index.xmlObject Browser, the Description pane will show the description, if available, for the highlight feature in the Memebers pane. The description will also show any obsolete messages and any preconditions and postconditions applied to the url*feature.
